result.execSummary:
The defendant Joseph T Jovanovic was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: All conditions of Probation previously imposed shall remain the same as conditions of Extended Supervision.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked or will discharge with outstanding financial obligations due, a civil judgment shall be entered for the balance due.
Defendant shall submit to random drug screens including blood, breath or urine.

Defendant shall not possess or consume any controlled substances without a valid prescription.  
Defendant shall not associate with any drug dealers or users.  
Defendant shall not be present in any place where controlled substances are illegally purchased, stored or sold.

Defendant shall provide a DNA sample.
Defendant shall maintain absolute sobriety.
Defendant shall notify any medical or healthcare provider of opiate addiction prior to obtaining a prescription.
Defendant shall obtain/maintain full-time employment or school.

timeConds.notes: Time shall be served with Huber privileges consistent with the rules of the jail while the inmate maintains a minimum security status. The defendant, at the discretion of the Sheriff, may perform community service work as an inmate worker in the county jail and shall earn statutory good time for same.
